title: Docker in the Toil appliance container does not know about --gpus
body:
@glennhickey says that you can't use the Docker client we ship in the Toil appliance with the newly-upstreamed `--gpus` option:

```
docker run -it --rm --gpus all  nvidia/cuda:11.4.3-runtime-ubuntu20.04 bash
unknown flag: --gpus
See 'docker run --help'.
```

We should update our Docker client to one that supports this option.

Related to #4199.

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Story](https://ucsc-cgl.atlassian.net/browse/TOIL-1247)
┆Issue Number: TOIL-1247

title: Toil jobs get stuck if `TOIL_KUBERNETES_HOST_PATH` doesn't exist on a node
body:
When Toil tries to mount the `TOIL_KUBERNETES_HOST_PATH` into its containers, it mounts it with a type of `Directory` and not `DirectoryOrCreate`.

https://github.com/DataBiosphere/toil/blob/88d73fbfd42ec22fd692940fc1efdacaf53b1b76/src/toil/batchSystems/kubernetes.py#L477-L478

This causes the pods to sit in `ContainerCreating` indefinitely, waiting for the directory to come into existence, if they get scheduled on a node that doesn't have the directory already.

The Kubernetes batch system itself doesn't notice this or time out the `ContainerCreating` pods, and so in our CI tests the whole Toil execution will be timed out, and killed without getting a chance to clean up its pods.

This is causing Toil CI failures, and also causing one of out Kubernetes nodes to become clogged up with these stuck, abandoned Toil pods.

We should change the Kubernetes batch system to time out pods that stay in ContainerCreating for some notion of "too long". We should also probably use `DirectoryOrCreate` as our hostpath volume type, because we probably want to be able to use this directory on our GI Kubernetes cluster even if nobody has gone around to all the nodes creating it.

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Story](https://ucsc-cgl.atlassian.net/browse/TOIL-1188)
┆friendlyId: TOIL-1188

title: `toil kill` doesn't cancel batch system jobs
body:
As noted in https://gitter.im/bd2k-genomics-toil/Lobby?at=618eb0f3fb3dcd4e88818830, `toil kill` doesn't seem to be using the normal shared file machinery to find `pid.log`, and when we reorganized where shared files live, it lost the ability to find it.

We should change `toil kill` to use the normal shared file read code, so it will always be able to find the files it is looking for, no matter where we store them.

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Story](https://ucsc-cgl.atlassian.net/browse/TOIL-1087)
┆friendlyId: TOIL-1087

title: nested directory getting lost between steps
body:
hi! I'm unsuccessfully trying to run our CWL pipeline with toil. It looks like somehow intermediate date products get lost. The pipeline runs fine with the CWL reference runner. My logfile is filled with errors like:

```
2017-11-26 11:19:34,177 - toil.leader - WARNING - W/2/jobLmwkno    WorkflowException: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: u'/vault-tina/gijs/prefactor-cwl/runs/run_2017-11-26-11-18-25/results/out_tmpdir2RF79v/calibrated.MS/OBSERVATION/table.lock'
```

The intermediate folder seems to be empty. My guess this is probably related to our data products being nested directory structures and maybe in combination with docker.

To reproduce this issue you could:
* clone our repository https://github.com/EOSC-LOFAR/prefactor-cwl/tree/b5c080d10c659232b46dd9dcb2d9e4c19cc9febc
* run `make toil` in the checkout

Requirements:
 * git-lfs
 * Docker
 * virtualenv

title: secondaryFiles referenced inside tool not included when running a CWL workflow
body:
__cwltoil__ doesn't copy secondaryFiles to the staging area if they aren't specified in the top level workflow file. I have a workflow that runs fine in __cwltool__ but fails with 
```
[Errno 2] No such file or directory ...
```
when run via __cwltoil__.

# Simplified Example
Details for a workflow with a single input data file that runs `wc` on it's secondaryFile.

### Workflow file `wc-workflow.cwl` 
This file has input __somefile__ that doesn't reference any secondaryFiles. I expected this to be inferred from the tool file.
```
cwlVersion: v1.0
class: Workflow
inputs:
  somefile: 
    type: File
  
outputs:
  classout:
    type: File
    outputSource: wordcount/output

steps:
  wordcount:
    run: wordcount.cwl
    in:
      somefile: somefile
    out: 
      - output

```
### Tool file `wordcount.cwl`.
Specifies __somefile__ has a secondaryFile with the extension `.log`. This tool returns the output from `wc <somefile>.log`
```
cwlVersion: v1.0
class: CommandLineTool
baseCommand: wc
requirements:
  - class: InlineJavascriptRequirement
stdout: output.txt
label: wc pairs of files
doc: wc pairs
inputs:
  somefile:
    type: File
    secondaryFiles:
      - .log
arguments:
  - valueFrom: $(inputs.somefile.path + '.log')
outputs:
  output:
    type: stdout
```
###  Job order file `wordcount.json`
```
{
  "somefile": {
     "class": "File",
     "path": "data.txt"
  }
}
```

How to run:
```
cwltoil wc-workflow.cwl wordcount.json
```
Fails with:
```
ValidationException: :1:1: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/var/folders/fs/vv08ppmd1mj7g35hyq5m_7nr0000gp/T/toil-86b1c2c0-787e-4edf-a008-baaae56a25f9/tmp4gDukI/987fdd3e-0cda-415c-8c97-76824e1fdd72/tuuC8qN/inp/tmpExS9RP/data.txt.log'
```

It works fine with cwltool/cwl-runner:
```
cwltool wc-workflow.cwl wordcount.json 
```

# Work around
If I change my workflow file(`wc-workflow.cwl`) to include the secondaryFile information(duplicated from the tool file) __cwltoil__ works fine.
```
cwlVersion: v1.0
class: Workflow
inputs:
  somefile: 
    type: File
    secondaryFiles:
      - .log
...
```

Here is the repo from this example: https://github.com/johnbradley/toil-secondary-bug

Thanks.

title: `toil create-cluster` fails due to missing image in quay

milestone.title: Sprint 8 2017
milestone.description: Release for mid to late July.

body:
Per the directions on http://toil.readthedocs.io/en/releases-3.7.x/install/cloud.html, I tried to create a test cluster like so:

`toil launch-cluster toil-spike --nodeType=t2.micro    -z us-west-2a --keyPairName=rk-toil-spike`

The process seems to stall while waiting for the toil appliance on the leader. From the logs of the leader we have:

```
May 23 19:54:46 ip-172-31-41-155.us-west-2.compute.internal dockerd[1139]: time="2017-05-23T19:54:46.255624733Z" level=error msg="Not continuing with pull after error: Tag 3.7.0-73c62d7698bb6f4154d276994df4353ce4d7826b not found in repository quay.io/ucsc_cgl/toil"
May 23 19:54:46 ip-172-31-41-155.us-west-2.compute.internal docker[23343]: /usr/bin/docker: Tag 3.7.0-73c62d7698bb6f4154d276994df4353ce4d7826b not found in repository quay.io/ucsc_cgl/toil.
```

Looking at quay.io, I can confirm that that image is no longer published. So it appears that the tool needs to be updated to reference a new image.

title: Tests leaking resources
If zone is not set the cluster utils fail very slowly
Fix bug in caching
body: Caching does not properly account for cached files "owned" by a job that was SIGKILLed, or one that failed on a node that was full enough to the point that even the cache file could not be updated. This PR will handle that issue to the best of Toil's ability. This is not critical to the 3.5 release.

title: Log level must be explicitly set for RealtimeLogger to work
body:
I have logging statements in my user code that log through the Toil RealtimeLogger. However, the RealtimeLogger doesn't get initialized unless I specify one of the Toil log level options (--logInfo, --logWarning, etc.). Without those I just get a message that it is disabled, even when I pass --realTimeLogging.

Instead, the real time logger should be enabled with the default log level if --realTimeLogging alone is passed.

title: Fix job scheduling on restart after partially failed DAGs
body:
If a job in a DAG fails and there is another path to its child, the child is run in the restart irrespective of the status of the previously failed parent in the new run.

@arkal will write a test to prove this behaviour and wither @cket or @benedictpaten will probably write the fix.

title: Worker fails to unpickle job if job arguments refer to user-defined types
body:
A JobFunctionWrappingJob/FunctionWrappingJob instance refers to 

1) the user module
2) the user function 
3) the args and kwargs for the function invocation

While 1) and 2) are symbolic references, 3) is not. The reason they are symbolic is to allow for the instance to be unpickled without having to load the user module. Once the job instance exists, we can use 1) to load the user module and 2) to extract the user function. If, however, the object graph from 3) references any types defined in the the user script, the unpickling will fail.

Update: I can't reproduce this without encapsulated jobs, so this seems to be specific to encapsulation. Moreover, what I describe above is partially wrong: the actual user script has already been loaded when the job instance is unpickled. This is because JobFunctionWrappingJob/FunctionWrappingJob override getUserScript() to return the module that the function is defined in. This module also contains the user-defined types, allowing them to be loaded during unpickling.

title: Toil appliance must start docker after mounting volumes
body: @cket and I ran into this bug this afternoon when testing out the autoscaler. On machines with multiple ephemeral volumes, the Toil appliance JBODs the volumes together and mounts them to `/var/lib/docker`, `/var/lib/toil`, etc. If this happens after the Docker daemon launches, docker fails sporadically when writing to `/var/lib/docker`, and the Toil appliance does an infinite failure loop.

title: Minor copy-paste error in worker.py
body:
I just stumbled across this:

https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/5ec9a2cd1fb081bd59a93a7aa0023d19cab6750b/src/toil/worker.py#L496

``` python
    #Close redirected stderr and replace with the original standard error.
    os.dup2(origStdOut, 2)
```

That should read `os.dup2(origStdErr, 2)` if you want to actually restore the original stderr to fd 2. I can't think of a way that this would ever cause a problem, though.

title: Job.Service needs access to the underlying job instance
body: We're running into this in https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil-lib/pull/46. Specifically, if the `Job.Service.start` method invokes a Docker container via [docker_call](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil-lib/blob/master/src/toil_lib/programs.py#L20) that cleans up the ghost container via a [`defer`red method](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/master/src/toil/job.py#L549), we need the wrapping `ServiceJob`. To do this, we can swap out the `fileStore` parameter that is passed in the `start`/`stop` methods with the underlying job (since the fileStore can be accessed through the job).

title: Implement FileIDs in NonCachingFileStore
Hot deployment localize() should catch EEXIST errors
body: Code currently catches ENOTEMPTY but EEXIST can also be raised.

title: Workflow directories are not cleaned up
body:
@Jeltje reports in https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil-scripts/issues/447 that the workflow directories are not being cleared up /var/lib/toil/toil-UUID. In a subsequent run, I've also seen on one of her workers that a previous workflow's directory was left on disk, a workflow that was terminated via Ctrl-C on the leader. It is possible the left overs from https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil-scripts/issues/447 were also caused by termination via Ctrl-C but that's not a reliable assumption.

It is also possible that the left-over workflow directories are breaking caching for subsequent workflows. @Jeltje and I saw the `assert cacheInfo.isBalanced` assert failing in a run where the leftovers were still present. An otherwise identical run on a clean cluster hasn't

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Story](https://ucsc-cgl.atlassian.net/browse/TOIL-102)
┆Issue Number: TOIL-102

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/jobStores/aws/jobStore.py", line 864, in loadOrFail
    raise NoSuchFileException(jobStoreFileID, customName=customName)
toil.jobStores.abstractJobStore.NoSuchFileException: File 'c2c91768-430b-4c96-b7ed-054753defe07' does not exist
```

_Copied from original issue: BD2KGenomics/toil-lib#24_

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Story](https://ucsc-cgl.atlassian.net/browse/TOIL-101)
┆Issue Number: TOIL-101

title: Hot-deployment fails with job functions spread over two top-level packages

milestone.title: Sprint 07 (3.5.0)
milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

body:
The following structure in a venv on the leader /path/to/virtualenv/lib/python/site-packages/toil_scripts
/path/to/virtualenv/lib/python/site-packages/toil_lib

causes hot-deployment to fail localization in a job function if parent job function is from toil_scripts.foo.bla while the other job function is from toil_lib.bar.fasel.

title: Autoscaling does not work with restarted pipeline

milestone.title: Sprint 07 (3.5.0)
milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

body: After a pipeline is stopped & its nodes are terminated, rerunning the script with --restart will not spin up any more workers.

title: Incorporate fix for tests leaking IAM roles and instance profiles

milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

title: Restarted job forgets about user script

milestone.title: Sprint 07 (3.5.0)
milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

body:
My script runs fine in a new job store (apart from some failing jobs due to errors from the tools they run), but when I go to restart the job, I get this:

```
WARNING:toil.leader:The jobWrapper seems to have left a log file, indicating failure: 52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9
WARNING:toil.leader:Reporting file: 52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       ---TOIL WORKER OUTPUT LOG---
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       WARNING:toil.resource:Can't find resource for leader path '/home/anovak/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations/scripts'
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       WARNING:toil.resource:Can't localize module ModuleDescriptor(dirPath='/home/anovak/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations/scripts', name='parallelMappingEvaluation')
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       ERROR:toil.job:Failed to import user module ModuleDescriptor(dirPath='/home/anovak/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations/scripts', name='parallelMappingEvaluation') from sys.path=['/usr/local/bin', '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip-8.1.2-py2.7.egg', '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/mesos.interface-0.22.0-py2.7.egg', '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/mesos-0.22.0-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg', '/usr/lib/python2.7', '/usr/lib/python2.7/plat-x86_64-linux-gnu', '/usr/lib/python2.7/lib-tk', '/usr/lib/python2.7/lib-old', '/usr/lib/python2.7/lib-dynload', '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages', '/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages', '/home/anovak/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations/scripts']
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       Traceback (most recent call last):
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:         File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/worker.py", line 316, in main
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:           job = Job._loadJob(jobWrapper.command, jobStore)
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:         File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 666, in _loadJob
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:           userModule = cls._loadUserModule(userModule)
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:         File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 640, in _loadUserModule
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:           return importlib.import_module(userModule.name)
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:         File "/usr/lib/python2.7/importlib/__init__.py", line 37, in import_module
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:           __import__(name)
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       ImportError: No module named parallelMappingEvaluation
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       Exiting the worker because of a failed jobWrapper on host amn2agent3
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       ERROR:toil.worker:Exiting the worker because of a failed jobWrapper on host amn2agent3
WARNING:toil.leader:52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9:       WARNING:toil.jobWrapper:Due to failure we are reducing the remaining retry count of job 52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9 to 0
WARNING:toil.leader:Job: 52d0d400_4080_480d_9c53_e7a7624b20e9 is completely failed
```

It looks like Toil is trying to import the user script, and failing. But this only happens with `--restart`; it imports just fine on the first execution.

I'm running with the AzureJobStore and the MesosBatchSystem, if it matters, with `--disableCaching` and with `--workDir tmp`. I'm relying on Toil to distribute the script and a "toillib.py" file that it imports, and that works just fine on the first execution.

title: `toil clean` doesn't clean up job stores on Azure
body:
I've been running jobs with Azure job stores, and I've been wanting to restart them from scratch. I'm supposed to be able to do this with `toil clean`, but it doesn't work.

```
anovak@amn2master1:~/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations$ toil clean azure:hgvm:amntree
amn2master1 2016-08-29 20:12:58,971 MainThread INFO toil.lib.bioio: Logging set at level: INFO
amn2master1 2016-08-29 20:12:58,971 MainThread INFO toil.utils.toilClean: Attempting to delete the job store
amn2master1 2016-08-29 20:12:59,034 MainThread INFO toil.utils.toilClean: Successfully deleted the job store
anovak@amn2master1:~/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations$ scripts/parallelMappingEvaluation.py azure:hgvm:amntree graph_urls.tsv azure:hgvm:pilot-input/reads azure:hgvm:pilot-output/low-coverage/aug16/out1 --batchSystem=mesos --mesosMaster 10.0.0.5:5050 --kmer_size=16 --edge_max=3 --index_mode gcsa-mem --include_primary --sample_limit 10 --disableCaching --workDir /tmp 2>&1 | tee log.txt
INFO:toil.lib.bioio:Logging set at level: INFO
INFO:toil.lib.bioio:Logging set at level: INFO
INFO:requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool:Starting new HTTPS connection (1): hgvm.table.core.windows.net
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripts/parallelMappingEvaluation.py", line 1170, in <module>
    sys.exit(main(sys.argv))
  File "scripts/parallelMappingEvaluation.py", line 1160, in main
    failed_jobs = Job.Runner.startToil(root_job,  options)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 540, in startToil
    with Toil(options) as toil:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/common.py", line 501, in __enter__
    jobStore.initialize(config)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/jobStores/azureJobStore.py", line 152, in initialize
    raise JobStoreExistsException(self.locator)
toil.jobStores.abstractJobStore.JobStoreExistsException: The job store 'hgvm:amntree' already exists. Use --restart to resume the workflow, or remove the job store with 'toil clean' to start the workflow from scratch
anovak@amn2master1:~/hgvm-graph-bakeoff-evaluations$ 
```

Thinking it could have been a timing thing with Azure, I've tried waiting a few minutes between the clean command and trying to re-use the job store name, but it hasn't helped. Clean is still reporting success, and Toil is still telling me that I need to run clean.

title: cwltoil non-clean job failures
body:
While debugging #1107 and responding to comments from @hannes-ucsc I realized the underlying issues with CWL restarts might be that cwltoil does not exit cleanly. Here is a small example with the test directory, forcing revtool to fail by messing up the `rev` command:

```
cd src/toil/test/cwl
sed -i 's/baseCommand: rev/baseCommand: rev-fail/' revtool.cwl
cwltoil --no-container revsort.cwl revsort-job.json
```

This fails with an assertion error during consistency checks at the end of `innerLoop` (https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/92f64a5d94bd16514979bc5c784f72863f2ddf5d/src/toil/leader.py#L728) which I suspect is not the right outcome. That function is pretty complex and deeply nested so it's not clear to me how to start debugging this. I hope that there's something we can include from the CWL side to create cleaner job exits here.

Can anyone offer any advice/directions?

Here is the full traceback from the run:

```

title: Global name 'config' not defined for getting azure job store
body:
`global name 'config' is not defined` error found in `toil/common.py` on line 617 in `getJobStore` when running toil version 3.3.1 on an Azure cluster. Error does not show up for toil version 3.2.1 and the toil script runs to completion. File `.toilAzureCredentials` is set properly.

Toil script command:
`./vg_evaluation_pipeline.py --batchSystem mesos --mesosMaster 10.0.0.5:5050 --realTimeLogging --logError --logDebug --edge_max 5 --kmer_size 16 --index_mode gcsa-mem --include_primary 'azure:hgvm:hgvmeval-jobstore33' --path_name 'ref' --path_size 81189 '/home/cmarkello/debug_eval_input/BRCA1.vg' '/home/cmarkello/debug_eval_input/BRCA1/NA12877/NA12877.bam.fq' 'NA12877' '/home/cmarkello/debug_eval_output' 'azure:hgvm:hgvmdebugtest-input' 'azure:hgvm:hgvmdebugtest-output'`

Toil script `main(args)` function:
`

```
if len(args) == 2 and args[1] == "--test":
    # Run the tests
    return doctest.testmod(optionflags=doctest.NORMALIZE_WHITESPACE)

RealTimeLogger.start_master()
options = parse_args(args) # This holds the nicely-parsed options object

with Toil(options) as toil:
    if not toil.options.restart:

        # Upload local files to the remote IO Store
        inputGraphFileID = toil.importFile('file://'+options.vg_graph)
        inputReadsFileID = toil.importFile('file://'+options.sample_reads)
        uploadList = [[inputGraphFileID, options.vg_graph], [inputReadsFileID, options.sample_reads]]

        # Make a root job
        root_job = Job.wrapJobFn(run_upload, options, uploadList, cores=2, memory="5G", disk="5G")

        # Run the job and store the returned list of output files to download
        outputFileIDList = toil.start(root_job)
    else:
        outputFileIDList = toil.restart()

    # Download output files to the local machine that runs this script
    run_download(toil, options, outputFileIDList)

print("All jobs completed successfully")

RealTimeLogger.stop_master()`
```

title: Auto-scaling creates twice as many nodes as needed

milestone.title: Sprint 07 (3.5.0)
milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

body: … because non-preemptable nodes are scaled up even though all jobs are preemptable.

title: Auto-scaler's notion of # of nodes will deviate from reality

milestone.title: Sprint 06 (3.4.0)
milestone.description:
Auto-scaling.

06/05/2016: Changed version number to 3.5.0 (due to skipping of previous sprint)
08/01/2016: Changed version number to 3.4.0 (don't know why it was 3.5.0 before and what it was before that)

Resulting pre-release is 3.4.0a1.dev228 (https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/releases/tag/untagged-04c9f90a0d8a6b6e69a9)

body:
First discrepancy occurs at start-up. If cluster already has nodes, auto-scaler will ignore them and scale as if they didn't exist. 

But also during normal operations, node failures and spot-market terminations will inevitably lead to deviation.

+        self.base_command = [sys.executable,
+                             '-m', 'toil_scripts.rnaseq_cgl.rnaseq_cgl_pipeline',
+                             'run',
                              '--config', self._generate_config(),
                              os.path.join(self.workdir, 'jobstore'),
                              '--retryCount', '1',
-- 
```

which produces

```
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:  Traceback (most recent call last):
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:    File "/mnt/ephemeral/workspace/toil-scripts/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/worker.py", line 316, in main
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:      job = Job._loadJob(jobWrapper.command, jobStore)
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:    File "/mnt/ephemeral/workspace/toil-scripts/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 631, in _loadJob
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:      return cls._unpickle(userModule, fileHandle)
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:    File "/mnt/ephemeral/workspace/toil-scripts/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 654, in _unpickle
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:      return unpickler.load()
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:    File "/mnt/ephemeral/workspace/toil-scripts/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 648, in filter_main
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:      return getattr(userModule, class_name)
ip-172-31-24-218: 2016-07-15 05:00:32,958 WARNING: toil.leader: V/c/jobC9b5iD:  AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'download_sample'
```

Debugging reveals that the job function is `map_job` from `toil_script.lib.jobs`. It's argument is the `download_sample` function from `rnaseq_cgl_pipeline.py` which is invoked as `__main__` via `-m toil_scripts.rnaseq_cgl.rnaseq_cgl_pipeline` (see above diff). The `userModule` is `toil_script.lib.jobs`. When unpickling the job, cPickle hits `__main__.download_sample` and `_unpickle` attempts to look that up in the `userModule` (`toil_script.lib.jobs`) where it isn't defined.

We can't always equate "main module" with "user module". Often it's the same, but sometimes it isn't. I got halfway to a fix by tracking userModule and mainModule independently but got stuck when `__main__` was `_toil_worker` which triggered the requirement that a module comes from a file ending in `.py` or `.pyc`. A fix for this might overlap with #858. If we know that a file contains python code, we can always resort to `imp.load_source()` rather then `importlib.import_module`. The only remaining problem is pyzipfile which would skip files with unknown extensions. @diekhans had a partial fix for this.

Then again, we are not interested in `_toil_worker` because nothing in it will ever be referenced by a pickled job. We might be able to just ignore non-.py `__main__` modules.

I haven't fully investigated this yet, but it looks like the harbinger file can be deleted by the asyncWrite thread after self.exists() is checked but before self.read() is called in waitOnDownload(). Maybe HarbingerFile.delete() should acquire the cache lock? Also, should line https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/edf86b5e253e9003a441a68773e79ecaded1a599/src/toil/job.py#L1613 be self.delete() instead of harbingerFile.delete()?

title: Streaming in AWS and Azure job stores masks exceptions

milestone.title: Sprint 04 (3.3.0)
milestone.description:
Robust clean, writeGlobalFile().size. Bug fixes.

06/05/2016: Moved due date by one week from 06/01/2016 to 08/01/2016.

body:
The AWS and Azure job stores (haven't checked Google) use the following pattern to facilitate streaming:

```
@contextmanager
def uploadStream(…)
    with os.fdopen(readable_fh, 'r') as readable:
        with os.fdopen(writable_fh, 'w') as writable:
            def reader():
                …
            thread = ExceptionalThread(target=reader)
            thread.start()
            yield writable
        thread.join()
```

If, during the yield, an exception is raised in the caller, the `with` statements will call close on the readable pipe even though the reader thread is still using it. This will cause

```
IOError: close() called during concurrent operation on the same file object.
```

to be raised which masks the original exception.

body:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python2.7
'''
Author : Arjun Arkal Rao
Affiliation : UCSC BME, UCSC Genomics Institute
File : toy_code_for_unfulfilled_promise_error.py
'''
from __future__ import print_function
from toil.job import Job, PromisedRequirement

import argparse


def test_test():
    '''
    '''
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('--dummy', dest='dummy', default=None, required=False)
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)
    params = parser.parse_args()

    F1 = Job.wrapJobFn(returner, disk='100M')
    F2 = Job.wrapJobFn(caller, F1.rv(), disk='200M')
    F1.addChild(F2)
    Job.Runner.startToil(F1, params)


def returner(job):
    job.fileStore.logToMaster(str(job.effectiveRequirements(job.fileStore.jobStore.config).disk))
    return 10


def caller(job, x):
    G = job.wrapJobFn(returner, disk=PromisedRequirement(oop, x))
    H = job.wrapJobFn(returner, disk=PromisedRequirement(lambda x: x, G.rv()))
    job.addChild(G)
    G.addChild(H)


def oop(x):
    return x + 1000


if __name__ == '__main__':
    test_test()
```

body: The recursive call to readGlobalFile (at this line: https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/3974681ac5b903c967ca31b59d6890e20761859d/src/toil/job.py#L1171) doesn't include the mutable argument, so the file gets read as non-mutable regardless of what the outer readGlobalFile was called with.

title: Spark master IP retrieved from wrong node
body: The `__init__` method of a service is not necessarily called from the same node as the service is actually run on. Because of this, the master IP of the spark cluster can't be determined in the `__init__` method. This manifests itself in connection failures once the service is running.

title: Cannot index promise if job returns another promise

milestone.description:

body:
If I have 4 chained functions:

A -> B -> C -> D

Where A returns `job.AddChildJobFn(B).rv()` and so forth until D returns a tuple ('foo', 'bar'),

```
a = job.wrapJobFn(A)
a.rv(0)
```

will return an error as it attempts to return the index of A, which is a promise, instead of the tuple in D.  @hannes-ucsc knows where in the code this bug originates.

title: Google job store does not validate name prefix
body:
Google imposes naming restrictions on bucket names see 
[https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/naming#requirements](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/naming#requirements)

As it stands the Google job store does not prevent the name prefix in the job store ~~string~~ locator from causing bucket names to violate these restrictions as is the case with name prefixes in the  Azure and AWS job stores and their respective component name restrictions.

title: Worker reports job success even when cache clean-up fails or never happens

milestone.title: Sprint 03 (3.2.0)
milestone.description:
Better caching, import/export of files on leader, promised requirements.

Does not include auto-scaling. Azure job store downgraded to experimental feature. Adds Google job store as experimental.

body:
Issue #963 brought up the issue where we were seeing jobs attempting to delete global files in use by other jobs (which shouldn't have been happening). @hannes-ucsc and I pinpointed it to being due to jobs saying they're completed and then being killed by bad worker before the job's temp dir was cleaned up. This left behind stale hard links that skew everything. Jobs should not be allowed to start the async update till their temp dirs have been cleaned up of all hard links.
I managed to reproduce teh bug in PR #972.

This Issue proposes to refactor Job._execute into 2 functions (names can be changed), 
1. Job._executor - A context manager that sets up stats and logging before the yield, and finishes up the stats and logging, and async updates the job after the yield
2. Job._runner - Actually runs the job, and serialises the next job(s)

worker.py will be modified to now have a nested context manager of Job._execute on the outside and job.fileStore on the inside such that the async update happens only after the cleanup has completed.

@benedictpaten  could you give us your comments on this when you can?

title: Google job store missing from getJobStoreClasses

milestone.title: Sprint 03 (3.2.0)
milestone.description:
Better caching, import/export of files on leader, promised requirements.

Does not include auto-scaling. Azure job store downgraded to experimental feature. Adds Google job store as experimental.

body:
`getJobStoreClasses` returns a list of job store classes for which the dependancies have been installed. The names of each job store class are hard coded into the method [see](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/master/src/toil/jobStores/abstractJobStore.py#L94). The `GoogleJobStore` class will never be included in this list because it is missing from the aforementioned hard coding. 

As a result calling `importFile` on a google-only supported url, `<url>` will result in a runtime error with the following message:
`No existing job store supports importing for URL '<url>'`

A --> C 
|       |
B      D

where A writes a file to the file store, B downloads it with mutable=True, then modifies it and writes it back to the file store with cleanup=False, and D downloads it. The test case I made with the above graph doesn't trigger the asyncWrite error, but the file store ID does have 444 permissions in job D.

title: Jobs with totally-failed successors will not wait for other successors to finish as intended
body:
This line in leader.py is broken and I'm pretty sure it will never evaluate to true:
https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/1195effda167eea9d1d623f2de0794c138de75b9/src/toil/leader.py#L756

The `toilState.successorCounts` dict is keyed by JobWrappers, not jobStoreIDs.

(The `__hash__` method of JobWrapper gives the same hash as its jobStoreID, but that only determines its bucket in the dict. `__eq__` is still used to compare items with the same hash value.)

I think the only side effect is that jobs with totally failed successors will terminate early as totally failed, rather than waiting for the successors to finish.

The fix should be trivial, let me know if you want it as a PR or to fix on your own.

title: Test parallelization garbles console output on Jenkins builds
body:
Due to test parallelization, the build's console is written to by multiple processes concurrently and therefore has to be taken with a grain of salt. In particular, it could be that the console says

fooTest: FAILED
barTest: PASS

but that in reality fooTest passed and barTest failed.

The console output that is captured and then listed per test will be correct and can be trusted. Only the overall console output will be bad.

title: Toil-scripts installed in venv causes Toil resolveEntryPoint error
body:
Trying to get pip installable toil-scripts to work in a venv causes a Toil error. Any cgcloud box with toil installed will work, a toil cluster isn't needed. 

To reproduce:

**Laptop**

```
cgcloud create-cluster --instance-type m3.large --leader-instance-type m3.large --spot-bid 1.00 --num-workers 1 toil

cgcloud ssh toil-leader
```

**Leader**

```
virtualenv --system-site-packages piptest

source piptest/bin/activate

pip install --pre toil-scripts
-----------------------------------
Collecting toil-scripts
Requirement already satisfied (use --upgrade to upgrade): boto==2.38.0 in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages (from toil-scripts)
Requirement already satisfied (use --upgrade to upgrade): toil==3.1.4 in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages (from toil-scripts)
Collecting pyyaml==3.11 (from toil-scripts)
Collecting tqdm==3.8.0 (from toil-scripts)
  Using cached tqdm-3.8.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Requirement already satisfied (use --upgrade to upgrade): bd2k-python-lib==1.10.dev6 in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages (from toil==3.1.4->toil-scripts)
Installing collected packages: pyyaml, tqdm, toil-scripts
  Found existing installation: PyYAML 3.10
    Not uninstalling pyyaml at /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages, outside environment /home/mesosbox/piptest
Successfully installed pyyaml-3.11 toil-scripts-2.0a2.dev179 tqdm-3.8.0
```

While pip says the requirement is already satisfied, something is wrong with the installation as Toil complains that it can't find an entrypoint:

```
INFO:toil.leader:Starting the main loop
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./piptest/bin/toil-rnaseq", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/home/mesosbox/piptest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil_scripts/rnaseq_cgl/rnaseq_cgl_pipeline.py", line 638, in main
    Job.Runner.startToil(Job.wrapJobFn(map_job, download_sample, samples, config), args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 445, in startToil
    return mainLoop(config, batchSystem, jobStore, rootJob, jobCache=jobCache)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/leader.py", line 392, in mainLoop
    jobWrapper.cores, jobWrapper.disk)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/leader.py", line 101, in issueJob
    jobCommand = ' '.join((resolveEntryPoint('_toil_worker'), self.jobStoreString, jobStoreID))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/__init__.py", line 45, in resolveEntryPoint
    assert os.path.isfile(path)
AssertionError
```

This error _doesn't_ appear and the pipeline can run locally if toil-scripts is installed outside of a venv.

title: cwltoil - does not read valueFrom correctly when scattering steps

milestone.title: Sprint 07 (3.5.0)
milestone.description: Auto-scaling with Toil appliance. Revived Azure job store.

body:
I'm attempting to run a [cwl workflow](https://github.com/Duke-GCB/GGR-cwl/blob/master/ChIP-seq_pipeline/02-trim-se.cwl) with cwltoil that uses `ScatterFeatureRequirement` and `StepInputExpressionRequirement`. For a few of the step inputs (not scattered), the value is wired to a `valueFrom:` constant. This causes the job to fail under cwltoil. The valueFrom expression does not make it into the job dictionary, and `fillIInDefaults()` raises an exception when the input is missing.

 The job runs successfully under cwltool (1.0.20160425140546)

I have a simple test case in https://github.com/dleehr/broken-valueFrom and can confirm it only fails when scattering:

Working: https://github.com/dleehr/broken-valueFrom/tree/1c3ff9be2a353ea8ac5cc0d95e9a61ebe89514f3

```

title: cwltoil does not pass setEnv variables to cwl job
body:
When running cwltoil with the `--no-container` option, jobs fail if the specified CWL `baseCommand` is not found in the runtime `PATH`. This is expected, but it seems there's no way to provide that path to cwltoil. There is a `--setEnv` argument that appears to be for this purpose (setting environment variables on jobs), but cwltoil does not honor it.

Running `cwltool`, the environment (including PATH) is inherited from the parent process/shell, so binaries specified in `baseCommand` are found if they're in the `PATH`.

cwltool command: 

```
PATH=$PATH:/home/dcl9/bin cwltool --no-container --outdir /home/dcl9/ggr-output/ /home/dcl9/GGR-cwl/qc/fastqc.cwl fastqc_job.json
```

results: [cwltool-succeed.txt](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/files/245337/cwltool-succeed.txt)

cwltoil command:

```
cwltoil --jobStore /data/tmp/toil-jobstore/ --no-container --setEnv PATH=/home/dcl9/bin --outdir /home/dcl9/ggr-output/ /home/dcl9/GGR-cwl/qc/fastqc.cwl fastqc_job.json
```

results: [cwltoil-fail.txt](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/files/245335/cwltoil-fail.txt)

```
2016-05-02 10:11:58,668 WARNING:toil.leader: P/p/jobGD9RLU: [job 28436624] /tmp/toil-24191727-ee15-4522-93b3-6be6f484b9a6/tmpIsrHjR/localTempDir/tyO2hO6/out$ fastqc -o /var/spool/cwl --noextract --format fastq /var/lib/cwl/job378892700_tmpSLsWRh/SRC1_ab2859_GR220236_6_160309_S18.tX_repX.fastq --threads 1 --dir /tmp
2016-05-02 10:11:58,668 WARNING:toil.leader: P/p/jobGD9RLU: INFO:cwltool:[job 28436624] /tmp/toil-24191727-ee15-4522-93b3-6be6f484b9a6/tmpIsrHjR/localTempDir/tyO2hO6/out$ fastqc -o /var/spool/cwl --noextract --format fastq /var/lib/cwl/job378892700_tmpSLsWRh/SRC1_ab2859_GR220236_6_160309_S18.tX_repX.fastq --threads 1 --dir /tmp
2016-05-02 10:11:58,668 WARNING:toil.leader: P/p/jobGD9RLU: 'fastqc' not found

title: Unable to import large files from S3 buckets

title: 'toil restart' doesn't work
body:
Any `toil restart` will fail, as far as I can tell, because a "realTimeLogging" option needs to be created.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/cluster/home/jcarmstr/venv/bin/toil", line 8, in <module>
    load_entry_point('toil==3.2.0a2', 'console_scripts', 'toil')()
  File "/cluster/home/jcarmstr/toil/src/toil/utils/toilMain.py", line 30, in main
    module.main()
  File "/cluster/home/jcarmstr/toil/src/toil/utils/toilRestart.py", line 59, in main
    toil.run()
  File "/cluster/home/jcarmstr/toil/src/toil/common.py", line 426, in run
    realtimeLogLevel = self.options.logLevel if self.options.realTimeLogging else None
AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'realTimeLogging'
```

I "fixed" this locally by adding a realTimeLogging option, but not sure if I should make a PR? There are some changes in #769 that affect the naming of some of the methods, but it still seems to expect realTimeLogging to be defined, so `toil restart` should still be broken in that PR as well.

body:
If two inputs to a cwl workflow step have the same name there will be a collision, for example:

```
2016-03-30 23:49:00,930 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU: ---TOIL WORKER OUTPUT LOG---

2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:   File "/Users/ellrott/workspaces/mc3_cwl/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil-3.2.0a2-py2.7.egg/toil/cwl/cwltoil.py", line 213, in run
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:     adjustFiles(cwljob, lambda x: getFile(fileStore, inpdir, *x, index=index))
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:   File "/Users/ellrott/workspaces/mc3_cwl/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cwltool/process.py", line 139, in adjustFiles
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:     adjustFiles(rec[d], op)
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:   File "/Users/ellrott/workspaces/mc3_cwl/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cwltool/process.py", line 137, in adjustFiles
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:     rec["path"] = op(rec["path"])
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:   File "/Users/ellrott/workspaces/mc3_cwl/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil-3.2.0a2-py2.7.egg/toil/cwl/cwltoil.py", line 213, in <lambda>

2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU:     raise Exception("Conflicting filesStoreID %s and %s both trying to link to %s" % (index.get(dstPath, None), fileStoreID, dstPath))
2016-03-30 23:49:00,931 WARNING:toil.leader: f/z/jobmQtiTU: Exception: Conflicting filesStoreID n/1/tmpxw47b3.tmp and L/C/tmpCnIrNm.tmp both trying to link to /Users/ellrott/workspaces/mc3_cwl/test_workflow/tmpzJ7dNP/localTempDir/tn7MTGE/inp/out.txt
```

Example Workflow (works in cwltool, fails in cwltoil):

```
- class: CommandLineTool
  id: "#echo"
  inputs:
    - id: text
      type: string
      inputBinding: {}

  outputs:
    - id: "fileout"
      type: File
      outputBinding:
        glob: out.txt

  baseCommand: echo
  stdout: out.txt

- class: CommandLineTool
  id: "#cat"
  inputs:
    - id: file1
      type: File
      inputBinding:
        position: 1
    - id: file2
      type: File
      inputBinding:
        position: 2

  outputs:
    - id: "fileout"
      type: File
      outputBinding:
        glob: out.txt

  baseCommand: cat
  stdout: out.txt

- class: Workflow
  id: "#collision"

  inputs:
    - id: "#input_1"
      type: string

    - id: "#input_2"
      type: string

  outputs:
    - id: "#fileout"
      type: File
      source: "#cat_step.fileout"

  steps:
    - id: "#echo_1"
      run: "#echo"
      inputs:
        - id: "#echo_1.text"
          source: "#input_1"
      outputs:
        - id: "#echo_1.fileout"

    - id: "#echo_2"
      run: 
        import: "#echo"
      inputs:
        - id: "#collision.echo_2.text"
          source: "#input_2"
      outputs:
        - id: "#echo_2.fileout"

    - id: "#cat_step"
      run: 
        import: "#cat"
      inputs:
        - id: file1
          source: "#echo_1.fileout"
        - id: file2
          source: "#echo_2.fileout"
      outputs:
        - id: "#cat_step.fileout"
```

Sample input:

```
{
  "input_1" : "Hello World",
  "input_2" : "How are you?"
}
```

body:
I experienced a weird case today where a job would hang on startup. When I killed the job (since it was hung; I killed it manually via `ps aux | grep toil` to get the pid and `kill <pid>`), the failure count would be reported as decremented... to 1, repeatedly:

```
WARNING:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:Task 31 failed with exit status -15
WARNING:toil.leader:Batch system is reporting that the jobWrapper with batch system ID: 31 and jobWrapper store ID: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec failed with exit value -15
WARNING:toil.leader:No log file is present, despite jobWrapper failing: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec
WARNING:toil.jobWrapper:Due to failure we are reducing the remaining retry count of job 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec to 1
INFO:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:Preparing to launch Mesos task 45 using offer d05e5caa-2e5c-44cb-a1d1-79ce6cec9eb5-O228155...
INFO:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:...launching Mesos task 45
INFO:toil.leader:Reissued any over long jobs
INFO:toil.leader:Rescued any (long) missing jobs
INFO:toil.leader:Reissued any over long jobs
INFO:toil.leader:Rescued any (long) missing jobs
WARNING:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:Task 45 failed with exit status 143
WARNING:toil.leader:Batch system is reporting that the jobWrapper with batch system ID: 45 and jobWrapper store ID: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec failed with exit value 143
WARNING:toil.leader:No log file is present, despite jobWrapper failing: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec
WARNING:toil.jobWrapper:Due to failure we are reducing the remaining retry count of job 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec to 1
INFO:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:Preparing to launch Mesos task 46 using offer d05e5caa-2e5c-44cb-a1d1-79ce6cec9eb5-O231848...
INFO:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:...launching Mesos task 46
WARNING:toil.batchSystems.mesos.batchSystem:Task 46 failed with exit status -15
WARNING:toil.leader:Batch system is reporting that the jobWrapper with batch system ID: 46 and jobWrapper store ID: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec failed with exit value -15
WARNING:toil.leader:No log file is present, despite jobWrapper failing: 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec
WARNING:toil.jobWrapper:Due to failure we are reducing the remaining retry count of job 3b2e3ae6-7a46-4686-99fa-5b0b7dc02eec to 1
```

I haven't deleted the jobstore for this run; it is `aws:us-west-2:fnothaft-toil-jobstore`. I can also send you a capture of the stderr/stdout from the toil leader, if that'd be of interest.

As an aside, there was other anomalous behavior with this job. Although the job was set to request all of the cores and memory from a single machine, it kept on getting scheduled on the same machine as another large job. Additionally, it wasn't clear why this job was failing. It would hang on startup, while a duplicate of the job got scheduled and ran on another node of the cluster. I'm rerunning right now with a different job store and will let you know if the error reproduces.

title: A failing root job causes EOFError
body:
Discovered while testing #686. To replicate:

``` python
options = Job.Runner.getDefaultOptions(self._getTestJobStorePath())
options.workDir = self.testDir
options.clean = "always"
options.cleanWorkDir = "onSuccess"
A = Job.wrapJobFn(tempFileTestErrorJob)
Job.Runner.startToil(A, options)
```

Where tempFileTestErrorJob is

``` python
def tempFileTestErrorJob(job):
    with open(job.fileStore.getLocalTempFile(), "w") as f:
        f.write("test file retention")
    raise RuntimeError()
```

The EOF error occurs when toil tries to unpickle the root job's return value:

```
    #Parse out the return value from the root job
    with jobStore.readSharedFileStream("rootJobReturnValue") as fH:
        jobStoreFileID = fH.read()
    with jobStore.readFileStream(jobStoreFileID) as fH:
        rootJobReturnValue = cPickle.load(fH)  #EOF here
```

We should probably catch this and instead raise a toil.leader.FailedJobsException as documented

title: logToMaster() doesn't work
body:
This is an example from the docs. It does not print the logToMaster() message, neither on master nor on 3.1.x.

```
from toil.job import Job

class HelloWorld(Job):
    def __init__(self, message):
        Job.__init__(self,  memory="2G", cores=2, disk="3G")
        self.message = message

    def run(self, fileStore):
        fileStore.logToMaster("Hello, world!, I have a message: %s"
                              % self.message)

if __name__=="__main__":
    options = Job.Runner.getDefaultOptions("./toilWorkflowRun")
    options.logLevel = "INFO"
    Job.Runner.startToil(HelloWorld("woot"), options)
```

title: Public URL to hot-deployed resources in S3 expires when IAM role creds expire
body:
If the leader is using temporary IAM role credentials, there are two expirations at play, they explicit one specified when the public URL is generated, and an implicit that happens when the IAM role credentials expire, usually after six hours. If workers are added or restarted after those six hours, they will likely get the following exception:

```
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    ---TOIL WORKER OUTPUT LOG---
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    Traceback (most recent call last):
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/worker.py", line 266, in main
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        job = Job._loadJob(jobWrapper.command, jobStore)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 937, in _loadJob
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        userModule = cls._loadUserModule(userModule)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 908, in _loadUserModule
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        userModule = userModule.localize()
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/resource.py", line 416, in localize
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        resource.download(callback=stash)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/resource.py", line 152, in download
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        self._save(tempDirPath)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/resource.py", line 269, in _save
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        self._download(bytesIO)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/resource.py", line 223, in _download
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        with closing(urlopen(self.url)) as content:
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 154, in urlopen
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        return opener.open(url, data, timeout)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 437, in open
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        response = meth(req, response)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 550, in http_response
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 475, in error
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        return self._call_chain(*args)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 409, in _call_chain
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        result = func(*args)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 558, in http_error_default
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:        raise HTTPError(req.get_full_url(), code, msg, hdrs, fp)
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    HTTPError: HTTP Error 400: Bad Request
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    Exiting the worker because of a failed jobWrapper on host ip-172-31-45-12
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    ERROR:toil.worker:Exiting the worker because of a failed jobWrapper on host ip-172-31-45-12
WARNING:toil.leader:e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba:    WARNING:toil.jobWrapper:Due to failure we are reducing the remaining retry count of job e8f55793-15ca-471a-947f-38936f917bba to 2
```

Existing nodes will not show this behavior because the resource was downloaded when the node first started. To be precise, the resources are downloaded once per Mesos executor process. If the executor fails after six hours and is subsequently restarted, this will also happen.

title: Nonetype object has no attribute "terminate"
body: An exception generated on interpreter shutdown while running SortTest. Seems benign but the exception should still be either avoided, caught, or documented. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1745232/solving-thread-cleanup-on-paramiko for more on this exception

title: Services are not stopped on Toil script failure
Allow uploading unowned files to file store
body:
This commit checks file ownership before trying to change the
permissions on a file that a job wants to put in the file store. If you
want to, say, store the local node's syslog file, or a file owned by
another user on a shared disk, we have to do this.

title: GridEngine BS should not redirect stderr and out to /dev/null
CWL secondaryFiles need to be copied into working directories
body:
Secondary files defined in CWL files (as part of the inputBinding) need to be copied into place.
For example in the case of a tool that defines a BAM file, and its index .bai file:

```
  - id: "#input"
    type: File
    inputBinding:
      position: 1
      secondaryFiles:
        - .bai
```

Will give the error:

```

Does not include auto-scaling. Azure job store downgraded to experimental feature. Adds Google job store as experimental.

title: AzureJobStore.clean() is very slow
body:
I'm attempting to restart a run with somewhere between several tens of thousands and hundreds of jobs in an AzureJobStore.

The first step of the restart process appears to be to "clean" the job store, which involves walking the entire job graph, in serial, before scheduling any jobs. With 100,000 jobs, and one (or more, with chunking) round-trip HTTP request to the strongly-consistent-but-slow Azure Tables system per job, all happening in serial, this could take a long time. It's already taken 25 minutes so far for me, which is time my cluster is just sitting there not doing useful work.

Ideally the cleaning process (and, if possible, all the scheduling) should be able to be done on-line, without deserializing all the jobs. It could just be implicit: if the modification timestamp on a job is earlier than the start time of the Toil run, we just fix up its retry count when we load it. At the very least the traversal should be able to be done in parallel, so we don't need to wait for the round-trip latency to the table service for every single job.

Toil should re-try its request in this situation, in hopes of reaching the server when it is less busy.

```

Both of these are instances of `insert_entity` throwing a retriable error, being retried, and failing the retry attempt due to a conflict. I think that the original insert is taking even though it returned an error, and thus the repeated attempt to insert the same thing (as opposed to updating it) fails.

Inserts should be retried as updates, or conflicts on retries of inserts should be taken as evidence of success (assuming Azure can't be made to accidentally make a partial insert).

title: Azure File Store Very Slow Download Speed

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

body:
My jobs that run on the Azure file store are hanging when downloading large files (where "large" is about 30 or 40 megabytes).

Here is a log on a singleMachine batch system with the Azure job store. It can run 2 jobs at a time (since I've set max cores to 32 and set it to use 16 cores in all my jobs), and right now those two jobs are both stuck trying to pull files out of the global file store: the cactus.tar.gz file should be 33 MB, as it was when generated using the file job store, and the snp1000g.tar.gz file should be 36 MB. It is taking far longer to download these files from the file store than it took to upload them; it's been waiting 11 minutes so far, for an overall download speed (on Kolossus, from Azure) of 0.10 MB/s or less. The line it seems to be hung in in my code is:

```
local_path = job.fileStore.readGlobalFile(index_dir_id)
```

The log from my code is here:
[logAzureStoreDebug.txt](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/files/41182/logAzureStoreDebug.txt)

It seems to work fine on the indexes for my smaller graphs, about 1-2 megabytes in size.

Unless this can get fixed quickly (or is not present in the current Toil release; I'm using master from a couple of days ago), I don't think I will be able to do my scale-up that I have planned for tomorrow.

title: Imported files in the same directory as the user script not available on Mesos nodes

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

body:
I have a particular user script that imports my own library code I have written for running on Toil, called `toillib.py`, which I keep in the same directory as the user script. I import it thusly:

```
from toillib import *
```

On the master, my script can import `toillib.py` just fine, but when running on Mesos on Azure, when there is no shared filesystem and Mesos has to take care of copying the user script out to the nodes, `toillib.py` appears to be missing when the workers start up:

title: cPickle serialization problem for WDL Task objects
body:
I get a stack trace when trying to pass a [Call object](https://github.com/broadinstitute/pywdl/blob/master/wdl/binding.py#L178) into a wrapped function in Toil:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "pickle_bug.py", line 46, in <module>
    print(Job.Runner.startToil(root, options))
  File "/Users/sfrazer/venv/wdl-cwl-toil/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 436, in startToil
    rootJob = job._serialiseFirstJob(jobStore)
  File "/Users/sfrazer/venv/wdl-cwl-toil/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 1248, in _serialiseFirstJob
    self._serialiseJobGraph(jobWrapper, jobStore, None, True)
  File "/Users/sfrazer/venv/wdl-cwl-toil/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 1216, in _serialiseJobGraph
    job._serialiseJob(jobStore, jobsToJobWrappers, jobWrapper)
  File "/Users/sfrazer/venv/wdl-cwl-toil/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toil/job.py", line 1178, in _serialiseJob
    cPickle.dump(self, fileHandle, cPickle.HIGHEST_PROTOCOL)
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```

This is the code to reproduce: (requires `pip install wdl`)

``` python
from toil.job import Job
import wdl, subprocess, io, re

wdl_code = """
task greeter {
  String name

  command {
    echo "Hello, ${name}"
  }
  output {
    String greeting = read_string(stdout())
  }
}

workflow test {call greeter}
"""

wdl_inputs = {
    "test.greeter.name": "World"
}

wdl_document = wdl.loads(wdl_code)

if len(wdl_document.workflows) != 1:
    sys.stderr.write('Current implementation requires exactly one workflow definition per WDL file\n')
    sys.exit(-1)

workflow = wdl_document.workflows[0]

def wrap_task(job, wdl_task):pass
def rootJob(job): pass

toil_tasks = {}
for task in wdl_document.tasks:
    toil_tasks[task.name] = Job.wrapJobFn(wrap_task, task)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    options = Job.Runner.getDefaultOptions("./toilWorkflow")
    root = Job.wrapJobFn(rootJob)
    for call in workflow.calls():
    root.addChild(toil_tasks[call.name])
    print(Job.Runner.startToil(root, options))
```

I imagine there's something about `cPickle` that I don't understand that I need to change in PyWDL

title: Can't specify disk requirement without specifying cache also

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

body:
Running the following user script

```
import sys
from toil.job import Job

def hello( name ):
    return "Hello, %s!" % name

if __name__ == '__main__':
    options = Job.Runner.getDefaultArgumentParser().parse_args()
    job = Job.wrapFn( hello, "world", cores=1, memory=1e6, disk=1e6 )
    result = Job.Runner.startToil( job, options )
    assert result == 'Hello, world!'
```

using this command line

```
python2.7 hello_world.py ./foo
```

Produces the following exception.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "hello_world.py", line 10, in <module>
    result = Job.Runner.startToil( job, options )
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 436, in startToil
    rootJob = job._serialiseFirstJob(jobStore)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 1246, in _serialiseFirstJob
    predecessorNumber=0)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/job.py", line 1104, in _createEmptyJobForJob
    " than the disk requirement for the job! (disk: %s)" % (cache, disk))
RuntimeError: Trying to allocate a cache (cache: 2147483648.0) larger than the disk requirement for the job! (disk: 1000000)
```

The user shouldn't need to specify cache. It should have a sensible default derived from the disk requirement.

title: Toil hangs on service initiation

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

body:
When I run the attached script with the command:

```
python bug_script.py --logDebug ./foo
```

it non-deterministically hangs, sometimes after starting the first service, sometimes after starting the second service. Sometimes it runs successfully to completion.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2.7
# Audrey Musselman-Brown

"""
Debugging Script
"""

import sys
import argparse
from toil.job import Job


log = open("bug_python.log", 'a')


def initialize(job):
    log.write("initialize\n")
    log.flush()
    job.addChildJobFn(job1)


def job1(job):
    log.write("job1\n")
    log.flush()
    job.addService(Service1())
    job.addChildJobFn(job2)


def job2(job):
    log.write("job2\n")
    log.flush()
    job.addService(Service2())
    job.addChildJobFn(hello_world)


def hello_world(job):
    log.write("Hello World\n")


# SERVICE CLASSES

class Service1(Job.Service):

    def start(self):
        log.write("start Service1\n")
        log.flush()
        return

    def stop(self):
        log.write("stop Service1\n")
        log.flush()
        return


class Service2(Job.Service):

    def start(self):
        log.write("start Service2\n")
        log.flush()
        return

    def stop(self):
        log.write("stop Service2\n")
        log.flush()
        return


def main(args):

    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()    
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)
    options = parser.parse_args()
    Job.Runner.startToil(Job.wrapJobFn(initialize), options)

if __name__=="__main__":
    sys.exit(main(sys.argv[1:]))
```

body:
As mentioned in the title, passing cache as a keyword argument to Job.wrapJobFn() does not work.
TOY CODE

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2.7
'''
Author : Arjun Arkal Rao
Affiliation : UCSC BME, UCSC Genomics Institute
File : toy_code_for_keyword_cache.py
'''
from __future__ import print_function
from toil.job import Job

import argparse
import time
import os


def f(job, test_val):
    '''
    This is a completely useless function.  It's only task is to be a called as
    a job by the test
    '''
    return None


def test_pass_disk_lt_cache():
    '''
    Try to run a job by not passing cache, but passing disk < 2GB (default value
    of cache).  This shows that the code has implemented the cache logic and the
    only problem is with the initializaton of the job.
    '''
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('--dummy', dest='dummy', default=None, required=False)
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)
    params = parser.parse_args()
    F = Job.wrapJobFn(f, memory='15G', cores=5, disk='1G')
    Job.Runner.startToil(F, params)


def test_pass_cache_val():
    '''
    Try to run a job by passing cache as a named keyword argument in the
    constructor.  This fails and shows that the constructor does not accept
    the keyword argument.
    '''
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('--dummy', dest='dummy', default=None, required=False)
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)
    params = parser.parse_args()
    F = Job.wrapJobFn(f, memory='15G', cores=5, disk='10G', cache='2G')
    Job.Runner.startToil(F, params)

if __name__ == '__main__':

title: AWS job store tests fail sporadically with 400 error on inlined files

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

title: Caching fails for large-ish files being written asynchronously to the jobStore
body: Following on from Arjun's tests we established that if a file was being written to the file store then it's local file could be cleaned from the cache, resulting in subsequent jobs trying to retrieve an incompletely written file from the jobStore.

title: Azure job store hangs in testLargeFile()
body:
I recently added coverage for writeFile() with large files. It turns out that Azure job store hangs on it. If've observed this on my personal machine and on Jenkins:

http://jenkins.cgcloud.info/job/toil-pull-requests/543/console

I'm moving the test into AWSJobStoreTest but ultimately it should be in the abstract base class.

To reproduce, move testLargeFile() to AbstractJobStoreTest and run it on AzureJobStoreTest.

title: Caching logic will fault if file_size > cacheSize
body:
Lines 680-686 in _cleanLocalTempDir 

```
            while totalCachedFileSizes > cacheSize:
                fileSize, fileStoreID =  cachedFileSizes.pop()
                filePath = self.jobStoreFileIDToCacheLocation[fileStoreID]
                self.jobStoreFileIDToCacheLocation.pop(fileStoreID)
                os.remove(filePath)
                totalCachedFileSizes -= fileSize
                assert totalCachedFileSizes >= 0
```

show that if totalCachedFileSizes > cacheSize the filePath is removed.

If a file larger than cacheSize is created, it is added to jobStoreFileIDToCacheLocation and it starts getting `os.link`ed however the _cleanLocalTempDir will delete the file before the link is complete. If the first thing in the next job is to retrieve this file from filestore ( which it probably will be), it will attempt to get it from filestore since it is NOT in cache.

However, depending on the file size, I/O, etc, if the file is still being written asynchronously to filestore, readGlobalFile starts processing an incomplete file. 

Either _cleanLocalTempDir needs to wat for the write to complete before deleting the file (since it is the rate limiting step), of readGlobalFile should have a way of asserting the integrity of the input file before reading it (Do not read a file till it is fully in filestore)

title: Caching is not compatible with files contained in folders called by getLocalTempDir
body:
For example,

```
A = job.wrapJobFn(a)
B = job.wrapJobFn(b, a.rv())
A.addChild(B)


def a(job):
    '''
    Align a file and return the filestoreID for the sam
    '''
    work_dir = job.getLocalTempDir()
    ...
    output_file = bwa_alignment(fastqs, outputdir=work_dir)
    #  Since output_file is in the scope of localdir, it will be cached
    output_file = job.writeGlobalFile(output_file)
    return output_file

def b(job, samfile):
    '''
    Convert SAMFILE to bam
    '''
    work_dir = job.fileStore.getLocalTempDir()
    #  Since samfile is in cache, the copy to samfile is passed
    samfile = job.readGlobalFile(samfile, os.path.join(work_dir, 'samfile.sam'))
    output_file =sam_To_bam(samfile, outputdir=work_dir)
    output_file = job.writeGlobalFile(output_file)
    return output_file
```

job B receives the cached copy of samfile which is in a folder returned by getLocalTempDir. While B starts its processing, A is actively deleting the temp local dir and B effectively processes a truncated version of samfile.

Using cache=False in readGlobalFile doesn't help because of line 544 in job.py

```
                    #If caching is not true then make a copy of the file
                    localFilePath = userPath if userPath != None else self.getLocalTempFile()
                    shutil.copyfile(cachedAbsFilePath, localFilePath)
                    return localFilePath
```

Even if i say don't use cache it copies the cached version of the file to work_dir.

title: writeGlobalFile probably needs a block if the input is a not-local file and won't be put into cache
body:
I have a test pipeline as follows

```
F1 = Job.wrapJobFn(aux.write_to_filestore, self.fastqs)
F2 = Job.wrapJobFn(aux.write_to_filestore, self.star_options)
G = Job.wrapJobFn(PI.get_files_from_filestore, F2.rv(), self.test_dir)
F1.addChild(F2)
F2.addChild(G)
Job.Runner.startToil(F1, params)
```

F1 writes two 4.5G fastqs to the jobstore
F2 writes a 24G tar.gz file to the jobstore
G in this example will attempt to retrieve the index.tar.gz from jobstore and untar it.

aux.write_to_filestore is

```
def write_to_filestore(job, files):
    '''
    This will write a dict of files to the write_to_filestore.
    The input FILES object is expected to be a dict of
    key = filename or sample_type
    value = filepath if key == filename
            list of filepaths if key == sample_type
    Eg. {'SRR123.fastq': '/data/SRR123.fastq',
         'sample1': ['/data/s_1.fastq', '/data/s_2.fastq']}

    FILES will be updated to
    key = filename or sample_type
    value = jobStoreFileID if key == filename
            list of jobStoreFileIDs if key == sample_type
    '''
    for name in files.keys():
        #  if list, replace the items with the filestoreID for each item 
        #  obtained from writeGlobalFile
        if isinstance(files[name], list):
            files[name] = [job.fileStore.writeGlobalFile(x) for x in files[name]]
        else:
            files[name] = job.fileStore.writeGlobalFile(files[name])
    return files
```

PI.get_files_from_filestore is

```
def get_files_from_filestore(job, files, work_dir, docker=False):
    """
    This is adapted from John Vivian's return_input_paths from the RNA-Seq
    pipeline.

    Returns the paths of files from the FileStore if they are not present.
    if docker=True, return the docker path for the file
    if the file extension is tar.gz, then tar -zxvf it
    files is a dict with
        keys = the name of the file to be returned in toil space
        value = the input value for the file (can be toil temp file)
    """
    for name in files.keys():
        files[name] = job.fileStore.readGlobalFile(files[name],
                                                   '/'.join([work_dir, name]))
        #  If the file pointed to a tarball, extract it to WORK_DIR
        if tarfile.is_tarfile(files[name]):
            files[name] = untargz(files[name], work_dir)
        #  If the files will be sent to docker, we will mount work_dir to the 
        #  container as /data and we want the /data prefixed path to the file
        if docker == True:
            files[name] = docker_path(files[name])
    return files

def untargz(input_targz_file, untar_to_dir):
    '''
    This module accepts a tar.gz archive and untars it.

    RETURN VALUE: path to the untar-ed directory/file

    NOTE: this module expects the multiple files to be in a directory before
          being tar-ed.
    '''
    assert tarfile.is_tarfile(input_targz_file), 'Not a tar file.'
    tarball = tarfile.open(input_targz_file)
    return_value = os.path.join(untar_to_dir, tarball.getmembers()[0].name)
    tarball.extractall(path=untar_to_dir)
    tarball.close()
    return return_value
```

If i comment out the `F2.addChild(G)` line then the data is successfully written to the filestore and the program exits normally.
If i don't, I get this Error almost immediately

```
[centos@arjun-fake-podk toil_tests]$ python module_tests.py
No handlers could be found for logger "toil.resource"

title: Make killBatchJobs consistent between batch systems
body:
Currently, the leader treats killed batch jobs separately from jobs that ended by themselves. JobBatcher.killJobs kills jobs and then sends them to JobBatcher.processFinishedJob, with the exit status manually set to 1. Also, in each iteration of the main loop, processFinishedJobs is called on the latest updated job. This means that if batchSystem.killBatchJobs adds the killed jobs to the updated queue, they will be processed twice. (single machine currently does this)
I think JobBatcher.killJobs shouldn't call processFinishedJobs, but all batch systems should add the killed jobs to the updated jobs queue with exit status 1. This means that all finished jobs are processed in the same place.

title: ParasolBatchSytem.killBatchJobs doesn't update results file
body:
Currently the parasol batch system uses "parasol remove job" in killBatchJobs, which completely deletes the job and prevents its status line from being written to the results file. Since the updated jobs worker gets its information from the results file, the CPU usage counter never gets decremented and getUpdatedJobs never returns anything about the job that was killed. The solution is probably to have killBatchJobs push the IDs of killed jobs to the updated jobs queue. 
This also creates a race condition because the job could end naturally before the "remove job" command is issued in killBatchJobs, which would alter the behavior of getUpdatedJob later on.

title: Does toil allow return values to be PromisedJobReturnValue instances
body:
I noticed this while reading the Docstring of Job.run

```
Note: We disallow return values to be PromisedJobReturnValue instances
(generated by the Job.rv() function - see below).
A check is made that will result in a runtime error if you attempt to do this.
Allowing PromisedJobReturnValue instances to be returned does not work because
the mechanism to pass the promise uses a jobStoreFileID that will be deleted once
the current job and its descendants have been completed. This is similar to
scope rules in a language like C, where returning a reference to memory allocated
on the stack within a function will produce an undefined reference. 
Disallowing this also avoids nested promises (PromisedJobReturnValue
instances that contain other PromisedJobReturnValue).
```

I have such an instance in my pipeline so i decided to test it out on a toy example.

```
from __future__ import print_function
from toil.job import Job

import argparse

def f(job):
    '''
    DOCSTRING
    '''
    G = job.addChildJobFn(g)
    return G.rv()

def g(job):
    '''
    DOCSTRING
    '''
    return 'test.foo'


def i(job, work_dir):
    '''
    DOCSTRING
    '''
    pass

def test_1():
    '''
    DOCSTRING
    '''
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('-f', dest='txt', default='txt')
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)
    params = parser.parse_args()
    F = Job.wrapJobFn(f)
    I = Job.wrapJobFn(i, F.rv())
    F.addFollowOn(I)
    Job.Runner.startToil(F, params)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    test_1() 
```

f is returning a PromisedJobReturnValue object of G and this should result in a runtime error, right?

title: singleMachine batch system disobeys --maxCores
body:
I'm trying to run a job on Juggernaut. Since I got unhappy e-mails when I discovered #425 when running on Kolossus, I want to only use half the cores on the machine (32 out of 64). So I ran my job thusly, with a `--maxCores 32`:

```
time ./parallelMappingEvaluation.py ./tree_high graph_servers.tsv ./reads_high ./out_high --sample_limit=3 --batchSystem=singleMachine --maxCores 32 --kmer_size=27 --edge_max=7 2>&1 | tee log_high.txt
```

In my script, I have all my jobs set to request 16 cores. So, only two jobs should be able to run at once, right?

Wrong! What actually seems to happen is that many jobs start up, and then they run until there are only two left, and then when one of those finishes a bunch more all schedule themselves at once, and the process repeats.

I think this is by design, as described [here](https://github.com/BD2KGenomics/toil/blob/master/src/toil/batchSystems/singleMachine.py#L122-L127). In the code associated with that comment, to run a job, a worker first acquires one thread (which by default is worth 1/10 of a CPU), and then tries to grab the full number of threads needed for the requirements specified by the job. However, it collects these extra threads non-blockingly, and if it doesn't manage to collect one before the lock attempt times out, it increments an `overflow` value and continues on as if it had actually gotten use of the thread and runs the user code. The net result is that more threads worth of user code can be running at the same time than one would predict based on the --maxCores argument. Although this behavior hasn't actually caused my job to fail, it is causing it to take up more CPU on Juggernaut than I want it to, and it could potentially lead to problems ranging from thread ulimit exhaustion to angry e-mails from other system users.

Please change the single machine job system to allow a user-specified hard limit on the number of cores worth of user code that will be run at the same time.
