Character values >=128 in job output crash Toil log retrieval

milestone.description: Caching, auto-scaling, inlining of files in SDB, batch creation of job wrappers and files.

body:
My user script invokes wget, which likes to output "smart quotes" to its standard output.

This standard output gets collected by toil, put into XML, and sent back to the master (at least when I run in debug mode).

Unfortunately, `ElementTree` assumes all its strings are encoded in ASCII, when it tries to encode characters with XML entities (like & and "), and it panics when it sees bytes >128, because it doesn't know what entities to use:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
          File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/worker.py", line 408, in <module>
            main()
          File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/toil/worker.py", line 392, in main
            jobStore.writeStatsAndLogging(ET.tostring(elementNode))
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 1126, in tostring
            ElementTree(element).write(file, encoding, method=method)
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 820, in write
            serialize(write, self._root, encoding, qnames, namespaces)
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 939, in _serialize_xml
            _serialize_xml(write, e, encoding, qnames, None)
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 939, in _serialize_xml
            _serialize_xml(write, e, encoding, qnames, None)
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 937, in _serialize_xml
            write(_escape_cdata(text, encoding))
          File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/etree/ElementTree.py", line 1073, in _escape_cdata
            return text.encode(encoding, "xmlcharrefreplace")
        UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 48: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Toil should assume an encoding for the standard output and standard error of the user script (probably UTF-8), and should strip or replace characters that can't later be encoded in the XML serialization format.

Sure enough, it's not installed. The Toil `setup.py` file lists only a dependency on `mesos.interface`, and none on `mesos.native`.

title: quick-start guide code is broken
body: The code in the Scripting Quick Start is broken because it uses optparse

title: Parasol batch system disregards cpu requirements
body:
Using the following user script, with a Parasol batch system, I can get nodes with only 32 cores to run jobs that request 1000 cores:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2.7
"""
simple_fail2.py: try to catch out Parasol Toin in mis-scheduling jobs

Theory: parasol tracks resource requirements *per batch*, not *per job*, so all
jobs will run with the CPU and memory requirements of the last job submitted.

"""

import argparse, sys, os, os.path, random, subprocess, shutil, itertools, glob
import socket, time, itertools

from toil.job import Job

def parse_args(args):
    """
    Takes in the command-line arguments list (args), and returns a nice argparse
    result with fields for all the options.

    Borrows heavily from the argparse documentation examples:
    <http://docs.python.org/library/argparse.html>
    """

    # Construct the parser (which is stored in parser)
    # Module docstring lives in __doc__
    # See http://python-forum.com/pythonforum/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=36847
    # And a formatter class so our examples in the docstring look good. Isn't it
    # convenient how we already wrapped it to 80 characters?
    # See http://docs.python.org/library/argparse.html#formatter-class
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description=__doc__, 
        formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter)

    # Add the Toil options so the job store is the first argument
    Job.Runner.addToilOptions(parser)

    # General options

    # The command line arguments start with the program name, which we don't
    # want to treat as an argument for argparse. So we remove it.
    args = args[1:]

    return parser.parse_args(args)

def root_job(job):

    for i in xrange(10):
        # Start a huge child
        job.addChildJobFn(child_job, cores=1000, memory="4G", disk="1G")

    for i in xrange(10):
        # Start a smaller job bigger than this one, so it will go to the batch
        # system
        job.addChildJobFn(child_job, cores=1, memory="4G", disk="1G")

def child_job(job):

    job.fileStore.logToMaster("Job needing {} cores running on {}".format(
        job.cores, socket.gethostname()))

    time.sleep(10)

def main(args):
    """
    Parses command line arguments and do the work of the program.
    "args" specifies the program arguments, with args[0] being the executable
    name. The return value should be used as the program's exit code.
    """

    options = parse_args(args) # This holds the nicely-parsed options object

    # Make a root job
    root = Job.wrapJobFn(root_job, cores=1, memory="2G", disk=0)

    # Run it and see how many jobs fail
    failed_jobs = Job.Runner.startToil(root,  options)

    if failed_jobs > 0:
        raise Exception("{} jobs failed!".format(failed_jobs))

    print("All jobs completed successfully")

if __name__ == "__main__" :
    sys.exit(main(sys.argv))
```

The underlying problem is that, while Toil tracks resource requirements **per job**, Parasol tracks resource requirements **per batch**: all the jobs in a batch share the same per-job resource requirements. So if larger and smaller Toil jobs are in the same Parasol batch, they will be scheduled according to one set of resource requirements--the resource requirements of the most recently issued job.

Parasol commands look like this:

```
parasol -verbose -ram=257698037760 -cpu=32 -results=/hive/users/anovak/ga4gh/bake-off/hgvm/tree_test/results.txt add job '/cluster/home/anovak/python/bin/python2.7 -E /cluster/home/anovak/build/toil/src/toil/worker.py /hive/users/anovak/ga4gh/bake-off/hgvm/tree_test c/F/job1s9mH_'
```

The resource requirements show up before the batch file, and they **update the resource requirements for all jobs in the batch**. The Parasol batch system code in Toil treats them as if they set the resource requirements for just the job being added. So if you add a big job and then add a smaller job (as in my script above), the big job will have its resource requirements lowered to match those of the smaller job, and may schedule on a node that can't handle it.

The Parasol batch system code in Toil should probably be rewritten to keep jobs with different resource requirements in different batches.

title: Single machine batch system swallows logs?
body: If exception occurs in worker,  the  message printed by leader should contain all logging done in worker if its above the configured log level. I don't _think_ it does.

title: Sort test has slowed down
body:
Runtime doubled to 13min. It started with my first stab at #274 (#275) and so I thought it was caused by it. Since then I made the existence check faster and more reliable (#283) but that didn't seem to have an effect. 

I did notice some "SDB is not available errors" today so maybe we should wait a bit.

title: Have toil write to /var/lib/toil
Have mesosbox write to /var/lib/mesos
Jenkins should only deploy to PyPI when building off the master branch
BadMesosExecutor is broken - in a bad way ;-)
body: It overrides a non-existant method.

title: toilStatus uses FileJobStore.loadToilState
body:
FileJobStore.loadToilState was deleted in commit 9f56a61044dded40705ce4a9711dc0f318496242, but toilStatus still uses it. I tried to fix this with:

rootJob = jobStore.load(config.attrib["rootJob"])
toilState = ToilState(jobStore, rootJob)

instead of:
toilState = jobStore.loadToilState()

This works some of the time, but sometimes it crashes saying that the child jobs don't exist.

title: Unit test logging problem
body:
Running MesosBatchSystemTest yields

No handlers could be found for logger "jobTree.batchSystems.mesos"

title: SingleMachineBatchSystemTest is defunct
body: Depends on #85

title: Worker logs contain duplicate messages
No visual indication of jobs timing out
body: When a job times out the job is rerun but there is no indication as to why the job is rerun. The timeout condition is logged on the worker but the log is never displayed on the master since the job is considered a success.
